title: Brexit secretary: UK will request extension if no deal by Saturday
text:
British Prime Minister Boris Johnson | Peter Summers/Getty Images Brexit secretary: UK will request extension if no deal by Saturday Stephen Barclay confirms the EU and the UK are discussing a revised political declaration.

LONDON — British Prime Minister Boris Johnson will comply with the Benn Act, which compels him to request an extension to Brexit negotiations if no deal is reached by October 19, the U.K.’s Brexit secretary said today.

Giving evidence to the House of Commons Exiting the European Union committee, Stephen Barclay said the U.K. government is committed to leaving the EU with a deal on October 31 and that this is the best way of avoiding having to comply with the Benn Act.

“I can confirm, as the prime minister has repeatedly set out, that firstly the government will comply with the law, and secondly it will comply with undertakings given to the court in respect of the law,” Barclay said.

In government documents submitted to Scotland’s highest civil court earlier this month, Johnson had accepted he must send a letter to the EU requesting an extension if no deal is agreed. Johnson was compelled to clarify his intentions to the court after anti-Brexit campaigners launched a legal challenge to prevent the prime minister from taking the U.K. outside the EU without a deal on October 31.

"Firstly the government will comply with the law, and secondly it will comply with undertakings given to the court in respect of the law." — Stephen Barclay

The Brexit secretary confirmed the EU and the U.K. are discussing a revised political declaration. He said he is confident parliament’s ratification of the withdrawal agreement could happen very quickly and could be finished by October 31, eliminating the need to seek an extension. “This is a House that can move very quickly when it wishes to do so,” Barclay said.

Asked whether he would be comfortable with an extension to tidy up the details if a deal is close, Barclay said: “No. It is important that we leave on October 31. I think the House has demonstrated through the Benn legislation, the Cooper legislation, its ability to legislate in a quick manner.”

The Scottish National Party MP Joanna Cherry, one of the petitioners of the Scottish court case, warned Barclay that sending a second letter to Brussels cancelling the request of an extension letter would amount to frustrating the Benn Act. But Barclay said he is “not aware” of any government plan to send two letters to Brussels. “I don’t think it is right and proper for me to get into detailed analysis of the law [Benn Act], interpretations, definitions and otherwise,” he added.

Commenting on the post-Brexit relationship between the U.K. and the EU, Barclay said the British government has no intention to deregulate its economy or to use state aid rules in a way that gives unfair advantage to companies in Britain.

“I don’t think there’s any desire to have a deregulatory approach. The question is to what extent do you have sovereign control of your regulation and what’s the interplay between your regulatory commitments and your market access … I’m sure that will be part of the discussion with the EU moving forward,” he said.

He added: “If you look at our starting point, the U.K. is not a country that has abused state aid and that is reflected by the position. So the idea that we would use state aid to advantage our businesses at the expense of those in Europe is belied by what the current data shows.”
description: Stephen Barclay confirms the EU and the UK are discussing a revised political declaration.
